title: Ticket #5150: Tools should apply reasonable projection for daemon location
description:
When querying the collector for daemon location, tools such as 'condor_q' get the kitchen sink - no projection is applied.

CMS has very large schedd ads (~100KB) because of the monitoring we have enabled. I've noticed that, on high-latency and/or low-bandwidth links, this transfer back to the client can contribute significant portion of the overall query time.

We should apply a projection on MyAddress.
remarks:
2015-Jul-17 11:07:27 by jfrey:
There will need to be a few more attributes in the projection, like CondorVersion.

2015-Jul-28 14:21:20 by jfrey:
The following attributes are consulted in the Daemon object. They would have to be part of the projection.

  • <subsys>IpAddr
  • Name
  • MyAddress
  • CondorVersion
  • CondorPlatform
  • Machine
  • AddressV1 and AddressV2 (for IPv6)

Additionally, the daemon's ad can be retrieved via a public method. In several places, callers query additional attributes, requiring potentially the full daemon ad. This could be handled by having an option to fetch the full ad. Here are the current places where more of the daemon ad is required:

  • condor_pigeon: a fragile attempt to lookup an attribute whose name ends with "PORT" from a pigeon ad.
  • condor_q: SwapSpaceExhausted, MaxJobsRunning, TotalRunningJobs, StartSchedulerUniverse, StartLocalUniverse
  • condor_config_val: -evaluate takes a config parameter's value and evaluates it in the context of the daemon ad
  • condor_history, condor_load_history: JobQueueBirthdate
  • python bindings: the daemon ad appears to be visible to python callers

2015-Aug-06 17:26:00 by tannenba:
I would like daemon location queries sent to the collector to be tagged specifically as "location lookups", not just as generic queries with a small projections. Ie the query ad to the collector should state that this is an address lookup. One reason for this is instead of just shortening the projection, I'd like these lookups to always use an index on the collector.

2015-Aug-09 05:37:37 by bbockelm:
The solution I ended up with was to differentiate between "LOCATE_FAST" and "LOCATE_FULL" in the Daemon::locate method (defaulting to LOCATE_FULL).

When LOCATE_FAST is used, CondorQuery indicates to the collector that this is a "location query" (in addition to providing a reasonable projection).

I went through and tagged as many tools as I had time to test (and, crucially, the negotiator lookup for the schedd's RESCHEDULE -- CMS has previously noted that this is an expensive lookup as it is done for every condor_submit; there's a ticket somewhere...).

If we go further down this road, we could consider flipping the default to LOCATE_FAST and marking just the tools Jaime noted which pull out the daemonAd. ( NOTE: we essentially did this in #6223 for v8.7.2 )

Finally, I changed the default for locate in the python tools to LOCATE_FAST. This was always the intent behind exposing a different "locate" versus "query" in the first place. We'll just note to users that they will need to switch to 'query' if they want the full ad.

2015-Aug-10 10:51:34 by tannenba:
Thanks Brian.... I'd be happy to code review when the time comes if nobody else does so...

2015-Aug-10 10:57:11 by tannenba:
Brian re your comment above about the expensive collector lookup that the schedd does upon a reschedule.... Hopefully that has been significantly improved after #4821 got pushed into v8.3.3.

2015-Aug-10 11:19:34 by bbockelm:
Yup - that should make a good improvement. However, there's still RTT between California and CERN to deal with - still seems silly to do it multiple times a second if every 'condor_submit' invokes a reschedule.

Anyhow, there ss a separate ticket for this: #4274

2015-Oct-21 10:55:22 by tannenba:
ToddM must sign off on this from an IPv6 perspective. Greg will consult with ToddM on some details here.

2015-Nov-06 11:06:19 by tlmiller:
This doesn't look like it will cause any problems for the IPv6 / multi-address work in the short-to-medium term. In the long term, we may introduce yet another address attribute, but this can be readily extended to cover that.
